Literature Review: Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy has revolutionized our understanding of microgels, providing unprecedented insights into their structure, dynamics, and properties. This literature review explores the application of 3D super-resolution fluorescence imaging techniques to microgels, highlighting key findings and future directions in this rapidly evolving field.Microgels are soft, deformable particles composed of cross-linked polymer networks that respond to various stimuli, making them attractive for applications in drug delivery, sensing, and adaptive materials. Traditional imaging techniques have been limited in their ability to resolve the intricate internal structures of microgels, particularly in three dimensions. The advent of super-resolution microscopy techniques has overcome these limitations, enabling researchers to probe microgel properties at the nanoscale.One of the primary applications of super-resolution microscopy in microgel research has been the investigation of morphology and shape. Conley et al. (2016) used 3D stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy (STORM) to visualize the deformation of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (pNIPAM) microgels at an oil-water interface. Their findings revealed that microgels adopt a core-corona structure, with a dense core and a diffuse shell of dangling polymer chains. This work provided crucial insights into the behavior of microgels at interfaces, which is essential for understanding their role in stabilizing emulsions and foams.The internal structure and cross-linker distribution within microgels have also been elucidated using super-resolution techniques. Gelissen et al. (2017) employed 3D direct stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy (dSTORM) to map the distribution of cross-linkers in pNIPAM microgels. Their results showed a heterogeneous cross-linker density, with a higher concentration in the core and a gradual decrease towards the periphery. This non-uniform distribution has significant implications for microgel swelling behavior and mechanical properties.Super-resolution microscopy has also been instrumental in studying the compartmentalization of microgels. Bergmann et al. (2018) used 3D structured illumination microscopy (SIM) to investigate the formation of interpenetrating polymer network (IPN) microgels. Their work revealed the spatial distribution of different polymer components within the microgel, providing insights into the synthesis and properties of these complex structures.The dynamic behavior of microgels has been another area of focus for super-resolution studies. Nöjd et al. (2018) employed 3D single-particle tracking to observe the diffusion of individual microgels in crowded environments. Their findings shed light on the complex interplay between microgel deformability and crowding effects, which is crucial for understanding the behavior of microgels in biological systems and dense suspensions.Recent advancements in super-resolution techniques have enabled researchers to probe beyond just spatial information. Späth et al. (2019) combined 3D super-resolution microscopy with fluorescence lifetime imaging (FLIM) to investigate the local polarity within pNIPAM microgels. This approach allowed them to map the hydrophobicity of the polymer network, providing valuable insights into the swelling behavior and phase transition of microgels.The integration of super-resolution microscopy with other analytical techniques has opened up new avenues for microgel research. Conley et al. (2019) demonstrated the power of correlative imaging by combining 3D STORM with atomic force microscopy (AFM) to study microgel adsorption at solid-liquid interfaces. This multi-modal approach provided complementary information on both the internal structure and mechanical properties of adsorbed microgels.As the field of super-resolution microscopy continues to advance, new opportunities for microgel research are emerging. One promising direction is the development of faster imaging techniques that can capture dynamic processes in real-time. Balzarotti et al. (2017) introduced MINFLUX, a super-resolution method that combines the advantages of STORM and stimulated emission depletion (STED) microscopy, potentially enabling rapid 3D imaging of microgel dynamics.Another exciting trend is the application of machine learning algorithms to super-resolution data. Ouyang et al. (2018) demonstrated the use of deep learning to enhance the resolution and speed of super-resolution microscopy. Such approaches could significantly improve the quality and throughput of microgel imaging, enabling more comprehensive studies of these complex systems.In conclusion, 3D super-resolution fluorescence imaging has dramatically enhanced our understanding of microgels, revealing their intricate structures, dynamics, and properties with unprecedented detail. As these techniques continue to evolve and integrate with other analytical methods, they promise to unlock new insights into the behavior of microgels and drive innovations in their design and application across various fields, from materials science to biomedicine.
